column4: Can anybody help me with this? I cannot log into my Gnome Desktop. My mistake was to send the command "sudo chmod -r *". Aftert this I wasn't able to login again. By logging in I got the error message ".dmrc has to have 644 rights and the home folder has to by owned by this user..." After doing the 644 chmod and chown commands I can login but the Gnome Desktop doesn't start. Pressing Alt+Ctrl+F1 works for getting into console.
boot to a console and fix the permissions of your drive.
permission of which drive?
the drive/partition you ran chmod on
basically, that chmod command you gave removed the read permission on *every file*. not good.
so whats the right command to change the permissions for the whole partition? chmod -R 644 * ?
you don't *want* every file to have read permissions. that's the problem. there's no easy way to undo what you did.
can u propose me the right mode for system folders and whats the right chmod for /tmp/ & /var/ ?
no, i cannot tell you the correct permissions for the hundreds of files in those directories.
I just burned my house to the ground. How can I use water and a copy of 'The Grapes Of Wrath' to rebuild my house from the ashes?  <-- same question ;)
a re-install is, without a doubt, the path of least resistance
no -R ?
sudo chmod -R -r * is really, REALLY bad. "sudo chmod -r *" is far less so.
which command was it? big -R there or no?
cd / && sudo chmod +r *
if so, that should in no way affect your ability to login
then the comamnd was not run from that directory, or was not the command you said you typed.
did you just open a terminal and type that command?
then you ran it in your home dir, not in ~/stuff
cd ~/ && sudo chmod +r *
just note that command i gave you. you should be fine.
don't worry about irssi right now. it's corollary.
